page.title: 04RIVER RIBBLE, PRESTON
page.content: Flowing from Ribblehead high in the Pennines,round the E,S and W of Preston, the{Ribble}joins the sea between Southport and Lytham. Famed for{salmon}before pollution from the growth of industry and the Dock,it gave the name to a main road , Fishergate.On 24.6.1768 as many as 3,384 salmon and trout were caught. In 1931 only 200 salmon were recorded. Less industry, and the Dock closure in 1982, means that the Ribble is again well_known as a Game and Coarse river. Six{bridges}go over the Ribble in our block:two railway bridges, one not used,the other being the main London- to-Glasgow line.The Tram Bridge is a relic from the old canal system.There are three road bridges:two 18thC., carrying main roads South and West, and one now a stone footbridge, but as the South bridge, of medieval origin.
